article.headline: Trump suggests North Carolina residents vote twice â which is illegal
article.body: President Donald Trump on Wednesday suggested North Carolina residents should try to vote twice â by mail and in person â in the November election, seemingly encouraging them to attempt to commit voter fraud in an effort to test the stateâs mail-in voting system. Trump made the comment during an interview with WECT News of Wilmington, N.C., when a reporter asked if heâs confident in the stateâs voting system, which could see 600,000 absentee votes cast this fall. âThey will vote, and then they are going to have to check their vote by going to the poll and voting that way because, if it tabulates, then they wonât be able to do that,â Trump said. âSo let them send it in, and let them go vote. And if their system is as good as they say it is, then obviously they wonât be able to vote. If it isnât tabulated, they will be able to vote. So thatâs the way it is, and thatâs what they should do.â iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } Voting twice is illegal under both North Carolina and federal law. In North Carolina, it is also illegal âto induceâ someone else to fraudulently cast a ballot. Trump has been a frequent and vocal critic of mail-in voting, claiming â without evidence â that it is susceptible to fraud. Trump himself has voted by mail a number of times. WECT said the way North Carolinaâs system is set up, it is âclerically impossible for a person to vote twice,â because once the mail-in ballot is received, the voter would not be allowed to cast a vote in person. When asked about Trumpâs suggestion Wednesday night on CNN, U.S. Attorney General William Barr said Trump was âtrying to make a point,â but declined to say whether voting twice is illegal (it unequivocally is), telling host Wolf Blitzer âI donât know what the law in the particular state says.â iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } Separately, federal prosecutors in North Carolina charged 19 noncitizens with voter fraud Wednesday, accusing them of illegally casting ballots in 2016.
